bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 15, 1944

div1.p: Kean encloses a copy of a positive review of Truby's book and makes comments.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 15, 1944
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
June 15/44
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
I had a nice letter from
Gen. Truby some two or three weeks
ago in which he sent me the inclosed
copy of a review of his book in the
British Medical Journal. He wondered
why the Jour. Amer. Med. Assn has
never published any review or notice
of it. So I have asked Gen. Ireland
to find out when he went to Chicago
to the meeting of the Council or what-
ever the governing body of the Am A is,
H is there this week and tho. he does
not like Fishbein, he promised to do so.
This inclosed review is I think an admi-
rable one and it naturally pleased Truby
much. Truby reports steady improve-
ment in his paralysed right arm
and that his speech, memory & mental
functions are all right. Isnt it rather
unusual that he should have had a right
side paralysis without involvement of
the speech center?

Let me have news of you when you can
find a stenog. who is not busy and
not thinking of her beaux. I am
very well and am happy in antici-
pation of seeing my son his wife &
my grandchildren J.R.K. II aged 14 and
Margaret, otherwise known as Peggy, aged 5½
on the 27th which is my 84th birthday. Mrs
Harry S. New (widow of the late Postmaster Gen.)
is giving me a dinner & the Irelands will be
there.

closer.salute:
With cordial regards
your friend sincerely
